description: From Middle English laste, latst, syncopated variant of latest.

entries.meaning: Final, ultimate, coming after all others of its kind.
examples: “Eyes Wide Shut” was the last film to be directed by Stanley Kubrick.

entries.meaning: Most recent, latest, last so far.
examples: The last time I saw him, he was married.
I have received your note dated the 17th last, and am responding to say that […].   (archaic usage)

entries.meaning: Farthest of all from a given quality, character, or condition; most unlikely, or least preferable.
examples: He is the last person to be accused of theft.
The last person I want to meet is Helen.
More rain is the last thing we need right now.

entries.meaning: Being the only one remaining of its class.

examples: Contending for principles of the last importance.
When we last met, he was based in Toronto.
I'll go last as I have to add the butter last.

description: From Middle English lasten, from Old English lǣstan, from Proto-West Germanic *laistijan, from Proto-Germanic *laistijaną. Cognate with German leisten (“yield”).

verbs.description: last (third-person singular simple present lasts, present participle lasting, simple past and past participle lasted)

examples: Summer seems to last longer each year.
They seem happy now, but that won't last long.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To hold out, continue undefeated or entire.
examples: I don't know how much longer we can last without reinforcements.

description: From Old English lǣste, Proto-Germanic *laistiz. Compare Swedish läst, German Leisten.

entries.meaning: A tool for shaping or preserving the shape of shoes.
examples: How is an in-your-face black leather thigh-high lace-up boot with a four-inch spike heel like a man's black calf lace-up oxford? They are both made on a last, the wood or plastic foot-shaped form that leather is stretched over and shaped to make a shoe.

verbs.description: last (third-person singular simple present lasts, present participle lasting, simple past and past participle lasted)

entries.meaning: To shape with a last; to fasten or fit to a last; to place smoothly on a last.

description: From Middle English last, from Old English hlæst (“burden, load, freight”), from Proto-Germanic *hlastuz (“burden, load, freight”), from Proto-Indo-European *kleh₂- (“to put, lay out”). Cognate with West Frisian lêst, Dutch last, German Last, Swedish last, Icelandic lest.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A burden; load; a cargo; freight.
(obsolete) A measure of weight or quantity, varying in designation depending on the goods concerned.
examples: Now we so quietly followed our businesse, that in three moneths wee made three or foure Last of Tarre, Pitch, and Sope ashes [...].

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An old English (and Dutch) measure of the carrying capacity of a ship, equal to two tons.
examples: The tonnage of the Duyfken of Harmensz's fleet is given as 25 and 30 lasten.

entries.meaning: A load of some commodity with reference to its weight and commercial value.
